Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 44233-01   
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
August 2010 
 
 
 
Knowledge Platform Development for the Asia Solar 
Energy Initiative
       
(Financed by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility) 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In May 2010, the Asian Development Bank announced its Asia Solar Energy Initiative 
(ASEI) to catalyze about 3,000 megawatts of solar power-generation projects over the next 
three years. ASEI’s broad objectives are to keep Asia and the Pacific abreast of technological 
developments in solar energy; identify and develop large-capacity solar projects; and design 
incentive  mechanisms  and  innovative  financing  mechanisms  for  rapid  diffusion  of  solar 
technology for power generation, both grid-connected systems as well as distributed stand-
alone generation. The initiative comprises three pillars: (i) an international knowledge-sharing 
platform, (ii) project development, and (iii) innovative financing. The first (knowledge-sharing 
platform), named the Asia Solar Energy Forum (ASEF), will organize international workshops on 
solar  energy,  track  solar  project  development,  and  assimilate  suitable  tools  for  appraising 
associated project proposals. The first meeting of ASEF was held in Manila during 5-6 July 
2010. Over 250 delegates from over 34 countries participated. 
 
2.  Regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) is currently being implemented 
for this initiative.1 The TA’s midterm report has concluded that a knowledge management gap 
exists for solar energy and smart grid2 development in Asia and the Pacific. Based on this 
identified knowledge management gap, the report reinforces the view that ADB, in partnership 
with  various  stakeholders,  developing  member  countries  (DMC)  governments,  donors, 
development partners, knowledge institutions, the private sector, and other stakeholders should 
help develop ASEF to mainstream solar energy and associated technologies in the region in a 
timely manner. This proposed TA will help create the ASEF as well as organize its second 
meeting in Tokyo in early December 2010.   
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Solar energy is regarded as one of the fastest-growing electricity technologies in recent 
years. Improvements in technology, cost structure, enabling policies, and regulatory frameworks 
have driven its spectacular growth in developed countries. Solar energy has great implications 
also for DMCs in Asia and the Pacific because (i) economies of scale can reduce costs to make 
solar energy competitive with conventional energy resources; (ii) some DMCs have greater 
solar radiation, more rapidly growing electricity demand, and more availability of land than 
developed countries; and, (iii) some DMCs have the potential to become global and regional 
manufacturing hubs for solar technology goods and equipment.  
 
4.  Strategy  2020  outlines  the  following  priorities  for  the  institution:  (i)  realizing 
environmentally sustainable growth for Asia and the Pacific; (ii) expanding its promotion of, and 
investment in, sound environmental management, while simultaneously capitalizing on ADB's 
operational strengths, such as infrastructure development and finance; and (iii) responding to 
climate change and supporting DMCs to move their economies onto low-carbon growth paths 
by expanding the use of clean energy.3 Further, its 2009 Energy Policy seeks to increase ADB's 
role  in  renewable  energy  development  by  facilitating  wider  technology  deployment,  raising 
awareness, encouraging policy and regulatory incentives to endorse use of renewable energy,

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
5.  This  regional  capacity  development  TA  will  contribute  to  an  understanding  by  all 
stakeholders  of  the  potential  for  solar  energy  in  the  region,  the  key  actions  required  to 
accelerate solar energy development, the institutional and business models for its development 
and deployment, and the mechanisms to promote technology transfer to DMCs and to enhance 
the scope for cooperation on research and development.  
 
6.  This initiative will cover (i) large-scale solar photovoltaic and concentrated solar power 
projects;  (ii)  grid-connected  distributed  solar  photovoltaic  projects;  (iii)  off-grid  solar  power 
generation projects; (iv) stable grid development projects using load management and two-way 
meters; and (v) associated technologies, such as lithium ion batteries, and plug-in electric 
vehicles. To mainstream such projects, a well-organized ASEF is critical, and it must involve 
DMC  governments,  the  private  sector,  research  and  development  agencies,  civil  society 
organizations, donors, and development partners.  
 
7.  ASEF will be useful for DMC governments in promoting foreign direct investment by 
international private sector companies. It will facilitate technology transfer by matching domestic 
and foreign companies (e.g., manufacturers, developers, suppliers, and financiers); mobilize 
concessional  funding  from  development  partners  and  developed  countries  to  structure 
financially viable projects; help optimize solar policy and regulatory framework to attract private 
sector enterprises to the fast growing market; and channel capacity development support from 
developed countries and development partners. 
 
8.  The private sector will have access to DMC government policy makers, acquire the 
latest information on DMC market development, develop consortia with foreign and domestic 
enterprises,  and  approach  development  partners  and  developed  country  governments  to 
provide financial assistance and TA with which the bankable projects can be developed. The 
ASEF will also be beneficial for ADB and its development partners in promoting regional and 
national policy dialogue, tailoring lending and guaranteeing operations to DMCs and the private 
sector, developing effective TA to match the needs of DMCs and the private sector, and sharing 
best practices. 
   
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The expected impact will be inclusive and low-carbon growth in Asia and the Pacific 
through increasing environmentally sound energy security with solar energy and stable grid 
development. The expected outcome will be the promotion and use of solar energy and stable 
grid development in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The proposed TA will comprise three components: (i) preparation, creation and initial  
operation of ASEF, (ii) organization of the second meeting of the ASEF in Tokyo, and (iii)

3 
 
identification and structuring of pilot projects for mainstreaming solar power generation. The 
outputs for the proposed TA are as follows.  
 
11.  Preparation, creation and initial operation of the ASEF. The participants at the first 
meeting of the ASEF held in Manila unanimously endorsed the conversion of the ASEF into a 
non-governmental,  not-for-profit,  organization.  This  TA  will  support  the  planning,  design, 
development, preparation, creation and operations of the ASEF for the first 2 years as an 
independent,  nonprofit  organization  involving  ADB,  DMC  governments,  the  private  sector, 
research  and  development  agencies,  civil  society  organizations,  donors,  and  development 
partners. Once fully established, ASEF will have its own staff, some may be seconded from 
participating private sector companies and others funded by contributions from ASEF members. 
 
12.  ASEF will seek to add value to the ongoing work of various organizations and initiatives 
in terms of investment, optimizing implementation arrangements, achieving economies of scale, 
and developing unified approaches to solar energy policies and programs. Its recommended 
roles will be to  
 
(i)  enhance communication among stakeholders; 
(ii)  develop  institutional  capacity  of  DMC  government  agencies  and  utilities  for 
utilizing  and  mainstreaming  solar  energy  and  associated  technologies  and 
products;  
(iii)  identify pilot projects, conduct pre-feasibility studies and structure utility-scale 
solar power generation and rooftop and/or off-grid projects; 
(iv)  help structure innovative financing for the pilot projects, by identifying possible 
concessional financial resources; and 
(v)  assist in the transfer of technologies for enlarging the solar energy market. 
 
13.  Organization of the second meeting of the ASEF in Tokyo. With identified partners 
and  network  participants,  the  second  meeting  of  the  ASEF  will  be  hosted  by  ADB,  the 
International Energy Agency, Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership, and the 
United Nations Industrial Development Organization. It will follow up on the outcome of the first 
meeting  of  the  ASEF  held  in  Manila  in  July  2010,  and  will  discuss  specific  measures  to 
overcome barriers for bankable solar photovoltaic, concentrated solar power, and distributed 
rooftop solar power projects, and sustainable off-grid and mini-grid projects using batteries that 
synergize electric vehicle development. The second meeting of the ASEF will also allow DMCs 
to promote foreign direct investment, the private sector to assess potential partnerships with 
foreign  technology  partners,  international  private  sector  project  developers  to  understand 
policies and incentive packages in DMCs, donors to consider user friendly concessional finance 
for  ensuring  commercial  viability  of  solar  energy  projects  and  to  explore  closer  donor 
coordination, and stakeholders to fill the perception gap.     
 
14.  Identification and structuring of pilot projects. Several solar energy project proposals 
will be identified during the discussions in ASEF in consultation with ADB, DMC governments, 
and project developers. Innovative measures to lower project risks, buy down the initial high 
capital costs, and make the projects bankable will be undertaken to support these projects. It is 
envisaged that a common set of tools will be prepared that can be used selectively in different 
DMCs with appropriate policy and regulatory environments. In some cases, prefeasibility studies 
will be supported in close cooperation with the project counterparts in DMCs.

4 
 
 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $2,000,000 equivalent, which will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing 
Partnership Facility.5 The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency for this TA. The solar technology team under the 
Energy Community of Practice will supervise the work of the consultants in close coordination 
with  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  and  various  operational 
departments.  
 
17.  Activities under this TA, including the preparation, creation and operation of ASEF and 
holding the second meeting, will require twenty two international person-months of consulting 
services for the first two years. The international consulting team will include (i) the chief 
executive officer for ASEF; (ii) two technical specialists for operation and administration of ASEF; 
and (iii) a forum producer for the meetings of ASEF. Further, three national consultants will be 
engaged for five person-months each, for a total of fifteen person-months. Outline terms of 
reference for international and national consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  International  consultants  will  be  separately  recruited  as  individuals,  as  flexibility  is 
needed in sourcing a broad range of specialists. ADB will recruit the consultants in accordance 
with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).6 In the medium to long term, 
ASEF will continue its operation without ADB’s TA support.  
 
19.  Equipment  for  ASEF  will  be  procured  under  the  TA  funds  by  ADB  according  to 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). An advance payment facility, to 
be replenished on liquidation, will be used to disburse funds to cover its administrative and 
operating costs. The ASEF will be required to maintain operation and administration accounts 
and have these accounts audited annually and reported to ADB. To facilitate the timely flow of 
funds and to reduce the administrative burden, the knowledge platform will be provided with a 
budget for travel expenses under the advance payment facility to be liquidated monthly. 
 
20.  Activities funded by this proposed TA will start in a DMC only after ADB has received a 
written statement of no-objection from the government. The TA is expected to be implemented 
over 18 months, from August 2010 to January 2012.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
 
21.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) for Knowledge Platform Development for the Asia Solar 
Initiative will require the services of the following consultants.  
 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The TA is expected to be implemented over 18 months from August 2011 to January 
2012. The professional positions and activities for the required positions are as follows. 
 
1.  Chief Executive Officer, Knowledge Platform (international, 4 person-months) 
 
3.   The activities of this consultant will include  
(i)  in collaboration with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) officer responsible for 
TA supervision, execute operations of the knowledge platform; 
(ii)  develop the annual schedule of workshops, meetings, training courses, and other 
activities; 
(iii)  convene, organize, and facilitate board meetings of the knowledge platform to 
deliberate on work plans and budgets, secure the necessary approvals, take 
minutes of the meetings, and disseminate these to all relevant parties (i.e., ADB 
and collaborating partners); 
(iv)  develop knowledge hubs in consultation with potential counterparts in Asia and 
the Pacific as well as in Europe and North America;   
(v)  develop business models of solar energy and smart grid development which is 
financially viable and sustainable;   
(vi)  prepare annual technical and financial consolidated progress reports, and submit 
these annually to the board of the knowledge platform; 
(vii)  monitor  progress  toward  the  TA  milestones,  inform  ADB  of  issues  and 
opportunity areas, and recommend actions; and 
(viii)  disseminate  information  to  and  communicate  with  relevant  stakeholders  to 
facilitate the work of the knowledge platform, particularly during conferences, 
workshops, and training. 
 
2.  Operation and Administration Specialists (two international, 5 person-months 
each) 
 
4.   The activities of this consultant will include  
(i)  in collaboration with the ADB officer responsible for TA supervision, and under 
the guidance of the chief executive officer, prepare, operate and administrate the 
knowledge platform, Asia Solar Energy Forum; 
(ii)  under the guidance of the chief executive officer, develop detailed agendas and 
schedules, manage invitations, organize sessions, and develop a website for the 
registration of solar energy forums; 
(iii)  Organize communication activities among the members and other stakeholders 
of Asia Solar Energy Forum;  
(iv)  Assist the members of Asia Solar Energy Forum to structure the business model 
and financially viable and sustainable projects   
(v)  under the guidance of the chief executive officer, develop the annual schedule of 
workshops, meetings, training courses, and other activities;

(vi)  assist  the  chief  executive  officer  to  convene,  organize,  and  facilitate  board 
meetings of the knowledge platform to deliberate on work plans and budgets, 
secure the necessary approvals, take minutes of the meetings, and disseminate 
these to all relevant parties (i.e., ADB and collaborating partners); 
(vii)  assist the chief executive officer to develop knowledge hubs in consultation with 
potential  counterparts  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  as  well  as  Europe  and  North 
America; 
(viii)  lead  the  planning  and  management  of  institutional  capacity  development  of 
satellite agencies; 
(ix)  draft  semiannual  technical  and  financial  consolidated  progress  reports,  and 
submit these to ADB at the semiannual and annual meetings; 
(x)  maintain and update a mailing list of all stakeholders, interested parties, and 
collaborating  and  development  partners  within  and  outside  of  Asia  and  the 
Pacific; and  
(xi)  disseminate  information  to  and  communicate  with  relevant  stakeholders  to 
facilitate the work of the knowledge platform, particularly during conferences, 
workshops, and training. 
 
3.  Forum Producer (international, 8 person-months) 
 
5.  This consultant will take the lead in organizing at least one forum for the pilot regional 
capacity development and knowledge sharing program. The activities of this consultant will 
include  
(i)  organize and implement one or two solar energy forums;  
(ii)  develop and implement a comprehensive program for logistics, including a forum 
time schedule and agenda; select and negotiate a conference facility and hotel 
accommodations for participants; and arrange transport and study tours; 
(iii)  consult with the relevant host country government agencies, co-sponsors, and the 
other stakeholders to develop agenda and ensure the quality of the forum;  
(iv)  nominate participants from stakeholders, and facilitate invitations; and 
(v)  conduct  relevant  press  conferences,  and  communicate  with  the  local  and 
international media; and  
(vi)  Conduct side events such as study tours.  
 
4.  Logistics Coordinator (three national, 5 person-months each) 
 
6.   The activities of this consultant will include 
(i)  support the international consultants in facilitating meetings and operating the 
forum,  including  logistical  elements,  documentation,  secretariat  services, 
dissemination of information and materials, and related support; 
(ii)  reimburse  selected  participants  for  travel,  hotel,  per  diem,  and  incidental 
expenses; and  
(iii)  conduct financing arrangements for the preparation of technical papers and post-
forum and program publications.
